ellencking: 100% recommend therapy. I think that everyone should have access to it and be able to go, just to hash it all out with someone completely unbiased who will be able to pick up on certain threads in thought patterns and help you work out reasons and coping mechanisms. Have a think about the sort of person you'd be happy to talk to (for me, it was a youngish woman) and see if there are any in your area. You can usually do a taster trial session to decide if they'll work well with you or not. Good luck!💕

claire_h_williams: Firstly - sending big hugs! I’ve been through this (and still going through it somewhat). I’ve had a lot of issues, have a Adenomyosis and fibro, anxiety and stress cause me to have tremors and seizures...it’s really affected me. I’m freelance and as you know, time off means no money. This has caused such a vicious cycle of crap. I’m in debt due to not working, feel that my life’s on pause, my new marriage had been hit hard by all this...I had too much to work through. I needed guidance so decided to get a life coach. She helped me tackle each of my problems and work out goals. We really talk about everything; goals, motives, fears etc. Since we started I started studying part time, managed to incorporate a bit of exercise, focus my career goals and also push for a much needed operation (which I’m super close to getting). Having someone to listen, guide and also hold me accountable (in the nicest way possible) has changed my life xxx

sarajeano: Still the best at what you do. Been following you and @calliethorpe for years from across the pond. 💜
bryoneycook: Any good therapist can and WILL deal with those things. Bear in mind many free services/NHS services depending on where you are, can only offer time limited therapy, so anywhere between 6/8/12 sessions. It really should be guided by you as to when it finishes and the one thing my clients said to me when I was on the 6th session (I was a student counsellor at a charitable organisation - loved it but 6 sessions flies in with each client) is that they often felt they needed more time. Also, don't be frightened after an initial meeting with a counsellor to not take up their services - the therapeutic relationship is important and it needs to be someone you gel with. There are lots of different approaches too, but not one approach fits all, so Integrative or pluralistic counsellors are skilled in many approaches - helpful when theres a lot going on. It sounds a lot, but honestly it's best if you don't feel comfortable to find someone else. The Counselling Directory is really good and generally has accredited counsellors, meaning they have either studied AT least to PG Dip level or have been assessed on over 450 hours of client time. Spot the Counselling nerd here. Ultimately, just look after yourself 💜
staceylauren2910: Hi Danie, I don’t know if this is an avenue that could be possible but... A few colleagues have used them for various things and honestly can’t rate them enough. See if they can help 💜

kidscookingandcosy: The ‘Priory Group’ can be a great place to start if you want highly qualified therapists. For each site you can access all staff, from therapists to Psychologists and Psychiatrists, and read the description and qualifications of each to find the one that sounds most suited. We’ve used the Priory Group twice across our family for different reasons. Because of these experiences I embarked on a Psychology degree which I finish next year. Powerful stuff when you’re in the right hands. I believe you can also contact the group and they can help you find an appropriate practitioner too. Wishing you well xxx

ccatherine_collins: Definitely see someone if you are thinking about it! Your regular doc should be able to refer you or do your own internet search before hand if you want to look at your options. bethprice245: I’ve recently started counselling, it’s early days but I think it will be helpful. I used an online directory to find counsellors in my area who specialised in the type of things I wanted to address and then contacted a few I liked the sound of. Most will offer a free telephone consultation so you can see if they’d be someone you’d be comfortable talking to and if it’s a good fit. I went for someone who offered a mix of CBT (coping mechanisms for anxiety) and humanistic (looking into what events in your life contributed to your issues and processing them healthily) therapy. I’m glad everyone is becoming more open and mental health and I think therapy needs to be normalised 💕
lipstick_and_flick: Something I find helps is to write down the thoughts that keep reoccurring. Then, categorise them - do I have any control/say in this? If not, I write next to the thought ‘there’s nothing I can do’. If I can do something about it, I prioritise and make an action plan with small goals a day. It might not work for everyone, but I find the visual reminder of what I can and can’t do really helps to focus my thoughts. Hope you come through the fog soon. xx
fromsarahlex: Was not prepared for this level of amazingness. Sending you so much love x
gomcp: The 1st thing to do is recognize that there is an issue & to STOP feeling guilty about it. Take the time to take care of you, worry about the rest LATER 👍🏽‼️

gtgmcg: I’m a MH commissioner so I’m happy to have a chat if that’s helpful. DM me. To be honest initially I’d point you to your local IAPT service. It’s free but you might have to wait a little bit. I found it really helpful in a very stressful period in my life.
bottrill: Babe I found a therapist through @welldoinguk they have a personalised matching service which I can vouch for, it’s obviously a ££ investment but I’ve had a few sessions with mine and it’s definitely something I want to commit to every single week and probably long term. Pls DM me about this stuff if you want to because it’s overwhelming and shit and difficult to know where to begin so if I can help at all I will. All my love 💖
the_colour_file: Hi lovely lady, so sorry to hear you’re struggling and well done for your courage in reaching out and telling people. I honestly think that therapy is the best money I’ve ever spent (well, that and IVF 😆). I went into therapy with the thoughts tangled in my head like spaghetti but I don’t feel like this any more. Such a relief. I think recommendations are always good. And someone local, if you can: in my experience it makes the whole process easier to stick to. Love and strength xx
kmhmmh: I also live with chronic illness (fibro and ME/CFS). Therapy has been a huge help in managing my life with illness. CBT, boundary setting and addressing the grief/loss of ‘healthy me’ were all extremely helpful. Best of luck.🙂
ashleighbrashagram: Take your time there’s no rush, we will be here when you are ready. Do what you need to do to keep your mental well-being sparkling✨ And just in case, love you 🤗🤗🥰😘
almassbadat: I can definitely recommend my therapist - she’s so gentle and listen so well, and is so intuitive too. Let me know bubs. I found her on baatn.org - took a chance xx
leighhutchi: I’ve had therapy through the NHS and free from a local charity. I’d recommend it to everyone. Brain dump on someone who has no pre conceived opinions or judgements on you who’ll help you put things into perspective. Big thumbs up from me ❤️
swanjackson: You are not alone...start with your GP...discover your options...Ask for a referral. Don't get disheartened. ..The fact that you are talking about it and seeking help are major achievements. ..good luck sweetheart!
curatorpolly: Troubled or not, you are looking resplendent my darling! ❤️👊
captainchar: Therapy has been the best thing I decided to undertake this year. I've done CBT and some other forms to treatment in the past but I could never quite get to grips and like you I felt more and more like I had a bunch of stuff going round on my head but nowhere to sort and order. I did a lot of research and finally decided on a lady and quite honestly she is amazing. Just to have a space and a time set aside to chat through all these open tabs is amazing. I chose to go privately so I was in control of how many times I could see her and even make it more of a long term thing but obviously you can do this through the NHS too.
becks_things: Get yourself a lovely notepad and pen, honestly it’s changed my life. Every morning I get up and write down what I need to do, even to the smallest detail like putting a wash on, to the bigger things like work and feeding my teenagers 😬😂 But it stops my mind from spiralling. I wake in the morning and my head races and I panic before the day has started, but now I have a cuppa in bed and write it all down and it instantly calms me. It’s such an achievement to strike things off throughout the day, and the notebook comes everywhere with me. Lastly, the calm app, it’s a life saver 🙌🏼🤩
campbey: You are so loved. You have been on my mind for a while based on your input on insta . I knew something was troubling you , sending you much love get on a plane and visit your brother take time out . Xx love to you and your family xx
iansangala: Ah man! Daniiii man 😭 Keep your chin up, you’re such a boss and have so many looking up to you, including myself! If I could achieve even 10% of what you’ve achieved, I’d feel over the moon! Check iMessage x
unique_rosch: Here for you always Danie ❤️❤️ Thank you for sharing. Life is bloody hard and we should own that shit! Mindfulness has been helping me lately 100% It just requires a conscious effort to do it, even when you can't be arsed because you always feel better afterwards 🙏🏾
whatagemcurve: Sorry to hear you’re having a tough time, I’d definitely recommend seeing someone to talk things through, it’s worked wonders for me and helped keep me going ❤️ You can use the Bupa treatment finder (even if you don’t have bupa) to find CBT practitioners/psychologists in your area and they all have blurbs about themselves and their specialist areas to help you choose the right person. Hope this helps ❤️
heathereighty: Therapy is a really good idea but remember there’s lots of different types of therapy and if you try one that doesn’t help, remember there’s others out there. I hope you start to feel back to yourself soon. It’s bloody hard. X
graceynoms: Finding something that works for you which might mean trying a few things - book an appointment with a GP and await a referral for therapy - in the mean time write a list off all the things stressing you out, then separate them Into what you can change and what you cannot change right now , then priorities them all and see if there is a check list you can create and slowly tick anything off. download an app called headspace which helps with meditation - anything that helps with breathing is always a bonus as well as exercise. Remember it’s a marathon not a sprint ❤️❤️❤️
itisjustjody: This is going to sound very cliché I don't mean it to at all. Close the tabs , one at a time, and in your own time. Your honesty and openness is the perfect place to begin. Thank you xx
shellymc: Omg, definitely do therapy! It's amazing and everyone can benefit from it if they are open to it. It can take time to find a therapist that you click with but sometimes friends have good recommendations! Also mindfulness and meditation were a gamechanger for me in terms of quieting that busy and sometimes critical internal traffic!
traybo77: First of all, sending a huge hug 🤗 A good therapist can take time to find. Firstly go to the BCAP website, as this will show you accredited therapists in your area and what issues they cover/types of therapy they offer. Try to get recommendations from people you know if you can. I’ve had about 4-5 in the last 10 years. Some I only saw once, but my latest one I’ve been seeing for a year and she’s literally saved my life. The most important thing is connection with that person, if you don’t feel that you can be totally honest with them, or the relationship just isn’t ‘right’, move on. I knew from my first appointment with my current therapist that she was the one, as I didn’t stop talking. Good luck lovely and we’re all here for you 💞 btw your content still rocks! Xx
zedk: I see @the_thomas_connection and would highly recommend her
kerry1803: Big love for sharing & being vulnerable on here that’s not easy 💜!! Honestly I wouldn’t know where to start with finding a therapist (Im considering doing the same after receiving brief counselling through work) I hope someone that does can help! One small thing that really does help get all of what’s going on in my head out is my @the_positive_planner it has great tasks (if that’s what you call them) that help you process what’s going on & it helps set intentions for the day & reflections too. I’d also recommend following @annamathur if you don’t already she’s incredible & maybe able to help on the therapist front. 💕😘
glambyruna: I feel this all the time and I ask the same question. What do I do? Do I need to talk to someone. These thoughts worries alone are draining. Thanks for sharing.
beepotts: Bacp.co.uk is one of the best places to look for accredited private therapists who are registered. You can search your area, issues etc to narrow down who/what you need. Journaling is a massive help I find - writing things down and seeing them in words sometimes helps make things clearer to see or understand. ❤️
lizzie_mcfarlane: Mindfulness an 8 week course was my first step. It was a gamechanger for switching off my brain. Doing things you love is so important. Regarding a councillor its important to know that not all councillors work for everyone. You have to find the right fit. Think dating but for therapy 😂. But once you find the one you are off. I still go but have gone from needing it weekly to every few months. If we always succeeded and had our shit together we would take it for granted. The darkness makes us appreciate the light. I am thinking of you. Sending lots of love and hugs ❤️❤️❤️
trixibelle_: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️ Just sending love and strength. You’re one of my favourite internet strangers. You’re such a strong, smart, go-getting person I know you’ll find the right help and it’ll just help you become even more excellent than you already are.
mrs_shepp: Sounds like therapy could really help you. I personally found it really beneficial. Love to you xx
rhymeswithsailor: Therapy changed my life. After my dad died I had all this pent up guilt over instances and I was sure it would haunt me forever and warp my relationships. My therapist helped me look at these situations in a different perspective which took the biggest weight off my shoulders that I had ever felt. I can’t speak highly enough of it. manlikepam: What’s for you will always be for you , try not to compare yourself with others , your path is different from other people , remember that your family and friends love you for who you are not what you are . abzieabditch: Therapy is incredible. Massively regret stopping to be honest and hoping to re-start soon. Those tabs definitely start to close when you work with a counsellor who is good at their job. Go for it- it could be the best thing you’ve ever done for yourself. X
